snippet.title: Miracles of modern medicine
snippet.content: IMAGINE a world where the miracles of modern medicine which we take for granted today were still 10, 20 and even 50 years away from becoming a reality. A world where cancer was still a mystery, smoking was allowed in hospital wards and nurses had to resign from their jobs if they wanted to have a baby. It's a far cry from the technology and facilities available today, not only in the big-city hospitals but also right here on the Sunshine Coast. The change has been as monumental as it has been rapid. People such as Mary Kiernan and Jean Haimes have not only seen the changes take place but also have been part of the process. It was a very different world when they began their nursing careers in the 1970s. They could hardly have forseen the transformation of the Sunshine Coast health care sector which now sees us enjoy access to a multi-million-dollar ultra-modern hospital which will not only provide first class health care but also train the health staff of the future. We are now home to several private hospitals while research under way at the USC Clinical Trials Centre may one day find a cure for cancer, asthma and other illnesses. We are also home to a world-class mental health institute, a rescue helicopter service which has saved countless lives, numerous wonderful health-based charities and a host of clinics which take advantage of our naturally healthy environment.
